title: Super fund for retail workers fights climate lawsuit
text:
Other factors, it says, include technological developments, trade agreements, the El Nino cycle, Brexit and interest rates.

Decisions about whether to make particular investments will also turn on a wide range of factors, such as the quality of management, strategic planning, future markets and capacity to recruit quality employees.

The significance of each factor will vary depending on each type of investment and how it fits into the overall investment strategy, the document says.

"The applicant has not identified any investment of REST [upon which climate change] ... will pose a material or major risk to its financial position," the document says.

Impact of rising sea levels

A hearing is scheduled for Tuesday in Sydney.

Mills Oakley partner Mark Bland said Mr McVeigh's legal team was looking to prove two things.

First, that REST had not made enough information available about the management of climate change risks to allow members to make an informed judgment about whether their money was safe.

Advertisement

The second – and more difficult task – was to prove the trustee had breached its duties by not doing enough to prepare for the effects of climate change risks on REST's investments.

Mr Bland said REST had conceded climate change was likely to result in sea level rises and other physical effects such as higher temperatures and more frequent droughts.

"What the fund's lawyers seem to be saying is that while REST accepts that physical impacts and transitional impacts of climate change are foreseeable and, in some contexts, material, REST cannot have known that they may have a material impact on its investment performance," he said.

“This approach may mean that Mr McVeigh has to prove that REST knew or ought to have known how particular risks to particular REST investments could materially impact REST’s broader investment performance.

"While the directors of REST are not party to the proceedings, the question of what REST knew, or ought to have known, may lead the proceedings to visit upon the state of mind of REST's directors."

Stress test

In other words, members of the board may be called to give evidence.

Mr McVeigh, who studied ecology and now works for Brisbane City Council, has the financial backing of Friends of the Earth. REST has two million members, many of whom work in retail.

Advertisement

Mr McVeigh's statement of claim alleges REST should have complied with the recommendations of the Task Force on Climate-related Financial Disclosures (TCFD).

For example, one of the TCFD's key recommended disclosures is for funds to stress test their portfolios based on a variety of different climate scenarios.

Mr McVeigh's claim also alleges the trustee must go to each of its external investment managers to seek information about how they are managing climate risks.

REST denies it is obliged to do so. It also denies being required to demonstrate compliance with the TFCD recommendations.
description: REST concedes climate change is a risk but doesn't admit the phenomenon will necessarily have a material impact on its investments, court documents reveal.
